messages.message: @Handsome Dave when will we build the next set of base images? I'd like to test out this change locally before UAT starts
@Ashish Is there a schedule for us to build base images, or should I just go ahead and do it?
Today is a good time right before the UAT due to start next week.

In general, base images can be built when build machine is available. However, updating the base image tag in deploy.mk (http://deploy.mk) needs to be performed carefully as it impacts all Instabase service builds on the master branch thereafter.
Hrrm. So I should build the prod deployment for LC on the old base images, right? Before doing anything else.
No, that won't be a problem. LC builds are created from a release branch. Your change will impact only the master branch.
(having said that I have stolen the old build machine for next 30 minutes for a branding change push to dogfood) :slightly_smiling_face:
Too late! I already built the lc prod images :stuck_out_tongue: But no harm either way.
@Handsome Dave have you built yet? asking because the ascii error is showing up in app tasks and image tasks on master :disappointed:
i can also comment out the code for now, but would love to get it fixed on master
I *just* kicked it off a few minutes ago, sorry.
I'll ping you as soon as they're available for testing
kk thanks!

@lydia Ok, the base builds are complete. If you want to test against them, please run `make BASE_IMAGE_TAG=19.10.18.19.03.56 run-docker` (or whatever docker build command you’re using). If you could verify that this fixes the issue you were seeing - and doesn’t cause any additional ones - then we can update `deploy.mk (http://deploy.mk)`
kk thanks
hey @Handsome Dave which version of pip and pip-compile do you have that it works properly? i'm getting a pip has no --no-cache-dir option which makes think i have a version skew issue
when i try to run pip-compile i mean
Huh. Nothing I did should have affected pip?
yea not related
i'm trying to pin our deps
what you did with apps-server, etc
my build was failing because a package wasn't pinned and it now requires python > 3.5
i think we're going to have a hell of a time with python EOL if we don't pin our packages
Are you talking about the `Dockerfile` stuff I did a month or so ago?
yea
i'm trying to use pip-compile to freeze the packages, but getting an error when i try to run it
That was just using the version of pip that was “shipped” in our py and py3 docker images.
oh you did the freeze inside docker?
I think you might be confusing Will and I, tbh. He was the one working with pip-compile.
I was the one moving around the existing Dockerfiles to be a single `RUN` stage, reduce the size, etc.
And Will was looking at “freezing” stuff, iirc.
oh kk you've never run pip-compile? maybe @dlluncor?
thanks! i'll see if i can figure out the issue
Yeah, it was definitely @dlluncor or @will
yep i’ve run pip-compile. Let me know if you need help with it at all
i'm good! i realized i just had a couple mistakes in the requirements.in (http://requirements.in) file

re: https://github.com/instabase/instabase/pull/11118 Lydia, I didn't know about this vulnerability. I suspect that this was flagged by GitHub Security Scan and as a result @dlluncor and @Aaron Vontell worked on it together.
yes that’s correct — GitHub flagged this issue on an older version of tensorflow — so Aaron upgraded the package that I approved
would it be ok if we downgrade it to 1.13.1? was the vulnerability on a much older version?

Here is the message from GitHub:

Upgrade tensorflow to version 1.12.1 or later. For example:

tensorflow>=1.12.1
Always verify the validity and compatibility of suggestions with your codebase.

So yes 1.13.1 looks OK from that standpoint!
@Handsome Dave tested the base image with app-tasks and image-tasks and it fixes the issue i saw!
Woot!
